lens.lens_summary: Kelly declined because the information architecture of discovery presented solution-data (guest attributes, schedule, flexibility) before problem-data (host exposure to payment risk, vetting burden, no recourse). Play Bigger's category design framework shows that information must be sequenced problem-first to open a new mental category. As Information Architect, the core finding is that every data element Kelly encountered was organized within the wrong category frame -- 'here is a tenant match' instead of 'here is the risk you carry and how we eliminate it.' The information hierarchy, labeling, content sequencing, and data transparency structures below address what should have been architected differently to prevent category-level rejection at discovery.

elements.title: Problem-First Information Hierarchy for Discovery Outreach
elements.problem: The information Kelly received was organized in a solution-first hierarchy: guest name, guest schedule, guest flexibility, guest duration, agent role. Every data point answered the question 'Who is this tenant?' -- a question Kelly never asked because she already has her own channels for finding tenants. Play Bigger teaches that 'winning companies today market the problem, not just the solution.' The information architecture of the discovery touchpoint (whether a call script, email template, or landing page) must invert the hierarchy: problem data first (what risks does direct hosting expose you to?), then category data (what is guaranteed-income hosting?), then solution data (here is a verified guest who proves the category works). Kelly heard solution data exclusively ('Landon is looking for Monday to Friday, three months, early February') and never encountered problem data or category data. The information hierarchy itself caused the rejection -- not the quality of the information within it.
elements.solution: Design a discovery information hierarchy that sequences content in three tiers. Tier 1 (Problem Layer): Surface the host's unresolved exposure. Structure as a question or scenario that activates recognition: 'If a tenant stops paying in month two, what is your recourse?' or 'When you rent directly, who covers damages if the tenant leaves?' This tier contains no mention of Split Lease, no guest details, no platform features. It is pure problem framing. Tier 2 (Category Layer): Name the new category and its core promise. Structure as a single declarative statement: 'We created guaranteed-income hosting -- you get paid whether the guest stays or not, and every guest is verified before they see your property.' This tier introduces Split Lease's category position but still contains no specific guest data. Tier 3 (Proof Layer): Present a specific guest match as evidence that the category works. Structure as concrete details: 'For example, Landon is a verified professional looking for Monday-to-Friday stays starting in February -- and your income is guaranteed from day one.' This tier is where Bryant's original pitch content belongs -- but only after Tiers 1 and 2 have been delivered. Apply this hierarchy to every discovery touchpoint: call scripts, initial emails, SMS outreach, and landing pages. The hierarchy should be visible in the content structure itself -- section headers, paragraph order, and visual weight must reflect problem > category > proof.

evidence.detail: Bryant's information sequence was: guest name (Landon) > guest need (part of the week) > guest schedule (Monday to Friday) > guest flexibility (start date, duration) > agent role ('matchmaker between guests and hosts'). Every element is Tier 3 (proof/solution data). Tiers 1 and 2 (problem and category) were entirely absent. Kelly received a well-organized answer to a question she never asked.

Play Bigger: 'A company that best frames a problem is the company that often comes to define and take the category. Put another way: winning companies today market the problem, not just the solution.' The information hierarchy must lead with the problem frame, not the solution data. Uber's information architecture taught us we had a taxi problem before it showed us the app.

Kelly: 'I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly.' This rejection occurred because the information she received was categorized within her existing frame ('here is a tenant from a site'). No information was presented that challenged that frame or introduced a new one. The hierarchy failed at the structural level.

elements.user_goal: Encounter information about my hosting risks before being asked to consider a specific guest, so I can evaluate whether my current approach actually protects me.
elements.company_goal: Restructure all discovery touchpoint content to follow a problem > category > proof information hierarchy that opens a new mental category before presenting any solution data.

elements.title: Risk-Contrast Comparison Card for Category Displacement
elements.problem: Kelly has a well-established mental model of her hosting approach: she finds tenants through nursing sites, vets them personally, and works with them directly. This model feels complete and satisfactory to her. Play Bigger's Anchoring Effect research shows that 'the first offer put on the table in a negotiation has a powerful impact on any other offer that comes after' -- Kelly's anchor is direct hosting, and she judges all alternatives against it. The information architecture never presented a structured comparison that would surface the gaps in her current model. Without a side-by-side risk contrast, Kelly cannot see what her current approach lacks because she has never organized the information that way. She sees 'direct = I have control' but not 'direct = I absorb all risk.' The information architecture must surface both sides simultaneously through a structured comparison format.
elements.solution: Design a risk-contrast comparison card that places the host's current approach and guaranteed-income hosting side by side, organized around risk dimensions rather than feature dimensions. The card does not compare features (listing reach, matching speed, platform tools) because feature comparison positions Split Lease as a competitor within Kelly's existing category. Instead, it compares risk exposure across dimensions the host cares about: payment security, tenant verification depth, damage protection, and legal recourse. For each dimension, show what the host currently absorbs personally versus what the platform guarantees. The card should be scannable in under 10 seconds -- the host should be able to see the risk gap at a glance. Visual weight should emphasize the risk column (what you carry now) more than the protection column (what we provide), because the goal is to surface the problem, not sell the solution. The card can be used in digital outreach (email, landing page), presented on-screen during a video call, or described verbally using the same structure during a phone call.

evidence.detail: Kelly: 'I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly... being more confident in who they were.' She evaluates her approach on one dimension only: trust through personal vetting. She has never been presented with the other dimensions -- payment risk, damage liability, legal recourse -- in a structured way that would reveal the gaps in her current model.

Play Bigger: 'An early company that solves the problem will win a powerful place in customers' minds. It becomes an anchor. Other companies coming afterward get judged against that early company.' The comparison card does not try to beat the anchor (direct hosting) on its own terms. It introduces new dimensions (risk exposure) that the anchor has never been evaluated against, forcing the host to reconsider the anchor's completeness.

Play Bigger on Birdseye: 'One early Life magazine ad showed a woman in pearls lounging on a pillow eating Birds Eye spinach, implying that only commoners put up with canned spinach. Frozen food was not just better than canned food -- it was different from canned food.' The comparison card must frame guaranteed-income hosting as different from direct hosting, not better. The risk dimensions are the 'different' axis.

elements.user_goal: See at a glance what risks I currently carry by hosting directly, compared to what would be covered under guaranteed-income hosting, so I can make an informed assessment of whether my current approach is truly complete.
elements.company_goal: Displace the incumbent category anchor by structuring information around risk dimensions that direct hosting cannot address, making the gap visible without attacking the host's current choice.

elements.title: Vetting Evidence Trail for Control-Oriented Hosts
elements.problem: Kelly's rejection centered on information access: 'I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were' (02:09). She wants granular, verifiable evidence about prospective tenants -- not a summary judgment from an intermediary. Bryant offered to 'get any information if there was anything that you need from him' (03:03), but this was a reactive, unstructured offer buried after the rejection. The information architecture of the guest proposal gave Kelly no structured evidence trail -- no verified employment data, no background check results, no payment history. The guest was presented as a name with schedule preferences, not as a verified profile with auditable evidence. For control-oriented hosts like Kelly, the information architecture must surface the vetting evidence itself -- the raw verification signals -- not just the outcome of vetting ('he is a good guest'). A trust badge or score would be insufficient because control-oriented hosts distrust summary judgments; they trust evidence they can evaluate with their own judgment.
elements.solution: Design a vetting evidence trail that presents each verification dimension as a discrete, inspectable data card with source attribution and verification date. The structure should include: (1) Employment verification card: profession, employer name, verification method (employer confirmation, professional license check), verification date. For Kelly specifically, this would show 'Travel nurse at [Hospital], license verified via state registry on [date].' (2) Identity verification card: government ID type matched, facial verification status, verification date. (3) Payment history card: number of prior leases on platform, missed payment count (ideally zero), average rating from prior hosts. (4) Background check card: check type, clear/flagged status, check date, provider name. Each card should be expandable -- showing the summary on first glance (5-second scan) with the option to drill into detail (30-second read). The host must be able to review all evidence before seeing any proposal terms. The evidence trail answers Kelly's actual question ('who is this person?') with more thoroughness than she could achieve through a nursing site profile or a phone conversation, reframing the platform as an upgrade to her vetting -- not a replacement of it.

evidence.detail: Kelly: 'I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.' She names two specific information needs: professional verification ('their nursing') and personal confidence ('who they were'). Neither was addressed in the call. The information architecture must answer both with structured, verifiable evidence.

Bryant: 'I'd be happy to get any information if there was anything that you need from him that I didn't have already.' This reactive offer acknowledges the information gap but does not structure it. The vetting evidence should be proactive (presented before the host asks) and structured (organized into inspectable cards), not reactive and conversational.

Play Bigger: 'Once you've committed to a product or service in a new category, you're likely to give positive qualities to an option you've chosen just because you've chosen it.' Kelly has committed to direct vetting. To overcome Choice Supportive Bias, the evidence trail must make the platform's vetting undeniably more thorough than what Kelly can do alone -- not just claimed, but shown.

Play Bigger: 'Product design is the purposeful building of a product and experience that solves the problem the market needs solved.' For control-oriented hosts, the problem is not 'finding a tenant' -- it is 'being confident in who the tenant is.' The vetting evidence trail is the product that fits this category of problem.

elements.user_goal: See exactly what has been verified about a prospective guest -- employment, identity, payment history, background -- with enough detail and source attribution that I feel more confident than I would from a phone call or an online profile.
elements.company_goal: Convert control-oriented hosts by demonstrating that platform vetting exceeds what direct vetting can achieve, while preserving the host's sense of evaluative authority through inspectable, card-based evidence architecture.

DO NOT hide verification details behind a login wall. The evidence trail should be shareable in the first touchpoint (email, SMS link) so the host can evaluate before committing to any platform interaction.

elements.title: Category-Defining Label System for Platform Vocabulary
elements.problem: Bryant described himself as 'a matchmaker between guests and hosts' (01:14). This label -- 'matchmaker' -- immediately categorized Split Lease within Kelly's existing mental model: a two-sided marketplace intermediary, like Furnished Finder or Airbnb. The label triggered instant classification, and once classified, the offering was evaluated within the wrong category and rejected. Play Bigger documents how Jawbone 'three times came up with cool innovations that created a brand-new product category. But three times, Jawbone failed to develop and dominate the category it created.' The failure was not in the product but in the labeling -- Jawbone was perceived as 'just another wireless headset' because its vocabulary mapped to the existing category. Similarly, 'matchmaker,' 'guest,' 'host,' 'listing,' and 'booking' all map to the tenant-finding intermediation category. Every label in the platform vocabulary must be audited and, where necessary, replaced with terms that signal the new category: guaranteed-income hosting.
elements.solution: Create a category-defining label system that replaces intermediation vocabulary with outcome vocabulary across all touchpoints. The system should include: (1) Role labels: replace 'matchmaker' with 'hosting protection manager' or 'account manager.' Replace 'guest and host' with 'verified occupant and property owner' in discovery contexts (guest/host can be used once the host has adopted the category frame, but not before). (2) Service labels: replace 'matching' with 'guaranteed placement.' Replace 'booking' with 'protected lease.' Replace 'listing' with 'protected property' or 'guaranteed-income property.' (3) Outcome labels: every label should pass the test: 'Does this word make us sound like what Kelly already uses?' If yes, replace it. 'We match you with tenants' becomes 'We guarantee your income.' 'We found a guest for your listing' becomes 'We have a verified placement for your property with guaranteed payment.' (4) Implement the label system as a reference document for all customer-facing content: call scripts, email templates, UI copy, marketing materials. Audit quarterly for vocabulary drift back toward intermediation terms.

evidence.detail: Bryant: 'I work basically as a matchmaker between like these types of guests and hosts.' This single sentence classified Split Lease as an intermediary. 'Matchmaker' maps to broker/middleman. 'Guests and hosts' maps to Airbnb vocabulary. Kelly's System 1 processed these labels and filed Split Lease in the 'platforms I prefer to bypass' category.

Kelly: 'That's a good opportunity that you offer, but I just prefer to work with the person directly.' She acknowledges the offering ('good opportunity') but rejects the category ('work directly'). The vocabulary failed to establish a different category. She heard intermediation labels and responded with an intermediation rejection.

Play Bigger: 'If someone in 2009 decided she needed a wireless headset, the automatic thought probably wasn't that she needed a Jawbone headset. More likely, she'd have thought: I'll go to Best Buy and compare products.' Jawbone's label ('wireless headset') placed it in a commodity category. If the label had defined a new category ('noise-canceling communication device'), the buying behavior might have been different. Split Lease's label ('matchmaker') places it in a commodity category ('tenant-finding intermediary').

Play Bigger: 'Category design is the mindful creation and development of a new market category, designed so the category will pull in customers who will then make the company its king. In marketing terms it is the air wars.' Labels are the primary ammunition in the air wars. If the labels map to the old category, the air wars are lost before the first shot is fired.

elements.user_goal: Immediately understand from the very first words I hear that this is something fundamentally different from the tenant-finding platforms I already know and have chosen to bypass.
elements.company_goal: Ensure every word a host encounters -- in calls, emails, platform UI, and marketing -- positions Split Lease in the guaranteed-income hosting category rather than the tenant-finding intermediation category.

elements.title: Local Social Proof Notification for Pre-Category Host Re-engagement
elements.problem: Kelly left the door open for future engagement: 'If anything changes or I have an associate that has a property or unit that would work, I will definitely give you' (04:12). She also revealed geographic affinity with Bryant ('I'm from Michigan, I saw the 248... I know your way, Troy'). This is a latent re-engagement thread, but the current information architecture has no structured mechanism to convert it into action. Play Bigger's Groupthink Bias research shows that 'when we hold an opinion that differs from others in a group, our brains produce an error signal, warning us that we are probably wrong.' Kelly will be more likely to reconsider when she learns that other hosts in Troy or Metro Detroit are using guaranteed-income hosting. But this local adoption signal must be delivered through a carefully structured notification -- not a sales pitch, not a guest match, not a feature update. The information must be organized as a single, scannable social proof signal: 'Hosts near you are using this.' If no local hosts have joined yet, the notification must not be sent -- fabricated social proof permanently destroys credibility.
elements.solution: Design a local social proof notification template triggered by geographic adoption milestones. The notification is sent to pre-category hosts (those who declined but left the door open) when a meaningful milestone occurs in their micro-market: first host joins within 10 miles, third host joins, first lease completes successfully, first review posted. The information architecture of the notification: (1) Geographic anchor: 'In Troy, MI' or 'Near you in Metro Detroit' -- the location comes first because it activates local identity and Groupthink Bias. (2) Social proof signal: '[N] property owners now use guaranteed-income hosting' -- the count is the core data point. No names, no details, just the aggregate signal. (3) Outcome data: 'with $[X] in guaranteed income paid this month' -- the outcome reinforces the category frame. (4) Low-pressure reconnection: 'Bryant is still your hosting protection manager if you ever want to learn more.' -- personal continuity, not a sales CTA. The notification should be deliverable via SMS (primary, for brevity) or email (secondary, for detail). Maximum frequency: one per meaningful milestone, no more than once per month. The notification must never include a guest match, a feature pitch, or a promotional offer. It is pure informational social proof.

evidence.detail: Kelly: 'If anything changes or I have an associate that has a property or unit that would work, I will definitely give you.' And: 'You're calling from Michigan, right? I'm right outside, I'm sort of in like Metro Detroit.' She revealed three re-engagement inputs: future openness, associate network, and geographic identity. The notification structure leverages all three: geographic anchor (Metro Detroit), social proof (local hosts joining), and personal continuity (Bryant as account manager).

Play Bigger: 'Groupthink Bias describes a tendency to believe things because other people do. Brain studies have shown that when we hold an opinion that differs from others in a group, our brains produce an error signal.' And: 'The people who already own iPads make the people thinking about buying iPads feel safer about the decision.' Local hosts who adopt guaranteed-income hosting make pre-category hosts like Kelly feel safer about reconsidering.

Play Bigger: 'Once a company wins a position as category king, a flywheel of benefits opens a gap between the leader and the rest.' Each notification is a flywheel signal -- it shows Kelly that the local market is moving toward the new category, increasing the social cost of staying in the old one.

elements.user_goal: Learn that other property owners in my area are successfully using guaranteed-income hosting, so I can reconsider from a position of social evidence rather than cold-call persuasion.
elements.company_goal: Convert pre-category hosts through local social proof by delivering precisely structured notifications at geographic adoption milestones that trigger Groupthink Bias without triggering sales resistance.

elements.success_metric: Pre-category host re-engagement rate: percentage of declined hosts who respond, request more information, or make a referral after receiving a local social proof notification. Target: 10-15% within 6 months of first local adoption milestone.
anti_goals: DO NOT send the notification if no local hosts have actually joined. Fabricated social proof permanently destroys credibility and violates the Groupthink Bias mechanism (it only works with real group behavior).
DO NOT include a guest match, feature list, or promotional offer. The notification is pure social proof -- one signal, one reconnection path.
DO NOT send more than one notification per milestone. Over-frequency converts social proof into spam and triggers the opposite of Groupthink Bias: reactance.

elements.title: Post-Rejection Category Seed Card for Declined Hosts
elements.problem: When Kelly declined, Bryant responded with 'Okay' (03:02) and then continued the same pitch. No structured category-defining artifact was delivered after the rejection. The call ended with a polite but formless goodbye. Play Bigger's 6-10 law shows that 'it always takes time to define a category, develop it, and change the way we see a problem and its solution. And that time is measured in years.' Kelly is a pre-category host whose timing has not arrived. The information architecture needs a structured post-rejection artifact -- a physical or digital takeaway that plants the category seed and gives Kelly a reference point when her circumstances change. Currently, the only information Kelly retains from the call is 'Split Lease is a matchmaker between guests and hosts' -- exactly the wrong category label. A post-rejection card must replace that label with the correct category frame so that if Kelly's direct tenant stops paying, or if she hears about guaranteed-income hosting from an associate, she has a mental anchor for the new category.
elements.solution: Design a post-rejection category seed card that is sent (via SMS or email) within 30 minutes of a declined discovery call. The card is not a follow-up pitch. It is a single-page informational artifact structured around the category definition, not the product. Content structure: (1) Category name as headline: 'Guaranteed-Income Hosting' -- this is what Kelly should remember, not 'matchmaking.' (2) One-sentence category definition: 'You get paid whether the guest stays or not. Every guest is verified before they see your property.' (3) One risk scenario: 'If a tenant stops paying in month two, guaranteed-income hosting means you still get paid through the full lease term.' This plants a problem seed -- the next time Kelly hears about a non-paying tenant (her own or a friend's), this scenario will trigger recall. (4) Personal reconnection anchor: 'Bryant -- your hosting protection manager in Troy, MI' with phone number. This maintains the personal relationship (which was warm) while reframing Bryant's role from 'matchmaker' to 'hosting protection manager.' No features, no guest matches, no call-to-action buttons. The card is designed to be glanced at once (5 seconds), then remembered later when circumstances change.

evidence.detail: After Kelly's rejection, the call continued for two more minutes with no category-defining information delivered. Bryant offered more details about Landon (same category frame) and Kelly offered a future referral (non-committal exit). No artifact was mentioned, no follow-up was structured, no category seed was planted. The only impression Kelly retains is 'matchmaker between guests and hosts.'

Play Bigger: 'It always takes time to define a category, develop it, and change the way we see a problem and its solution. And that time is measured in years.' The category seed card is designed for this timeline. It does not expect immediate conversion. It plants a mental reference point that becomes relevant when Kelly's circumstances change -- a tenant stops paying, a friend reports a bad experience, or local social proof accumulates.

The geographic exchange ('I'm from Michigan, I saw the 248... I know your way, Troy') established personal warmth. The seed card should leverage this warmth by anchoring Bryant as a local contact, not a remote sales agent. The personal connection is the retention asset; the card gives it a category frame.

Play Bigger: 'The first offer put on the table in a negotiation has a powerful impact on any other offer that comes after.' The seed card replaces the first anchor ('matchmaker') with a new anchor ('guaranteed-income hosting'). If Kelly ever reconsiders, she will now judge the opportunity against the correct category frame rather than the intermediation frame.

elements.user_goal: Have a clear, non-pushy reference for what guaranteed-income hosting means, so that if my situation changes or a friend asks, I know exactly what it is and who to contact.
elements.company_goal: Replace the incorrect category label ('matchmaker') in the declined host's mind with the correct category label ('guaranteed-income hosting') through a single, scannable artifact that serves as a long-term mental anchor.
